content: Singapore political family The **Lee family** ([lì]; [Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_language): 李; [pinyin](/wiki/Pinyin): *Lǐ*) is a [political family](/wiki/Political_family) in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore), with members prominent in [Singaporean politics](/wiki/Politics_of_Singapore), public service, law, business and academia. ## Background The son of [Lee Chin Koon](/wiki/Lee_Chin_Koon) and [Chua Jim Neo](/wiki/Chua_Jim_Neo), [Lee Kuan Yew](/wiki/Lee_Kuan_Yew) served as the first [Prime Minister of Singapore](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Singapore) and his eldest son [Lee Hsien Loong](/wiki/Lee_Hsien_Loong) served as the third Prime Minister. Members of the Lee family also held leadership positions in the [People's Action Party](/wiki/People%27s_Action_Party) which forms the incumbent [Government of Singapore](/wiki/Government_of_Singapore). ## Family tree Family tree of Lee Kuan YewLee Bok Boon 1846–1920Seow Huan Neo 1850–c. 1931Lee Hoon Leong 1871–1942Ko Liem Nio 1883–1959[Lee Chin Koon](/wiki/Lee_Chin_Koon) 1903–1997[Chua Jim Neo](/wiki/Chua_Jim_Neo) 1907–1980[Lee Kuan Yew](/wiki/Lee_Kuan_Yew) 1923–2015[Kwa Geok Choo](/wiki/Kwa_Geok_Choo) 1920–2010Dennis Lee Kim Yew 1925–2003Gloria Lee (Woo) Sau Yin 1926–2023Freddy Lee Thiam Yew 1927–2012Eleanor Ngo Puay ChinMonica Lee Kim Mon b. 1929George Chan Chor CheungDr Lee Suan Yew b. 1933Pamela ChongWong Ming Yang 1951–1982[Lee Hsien Loong](/wiki/Lee_Hsien_Loong) b. 1952[Ho Ching](/wiki/Ho_Ching) b. 1953[Lee Wei Ling](/wiki/Lee_Wei_Ling) 1955–2024[Lee Hsien Yang](/wiki/Lee_Hsien_Yang) b. 1957Lim Suet Fern b. 1958Li Xiuqi b. 1981Li Yipeng b. 1982[Li Hongyi](/wiki/Li_Hongyi_(administrator)) b. 1987Li Haoyi b. 1989[Li Shengwu](/wiki/Li_Shengwu_(economist)) b. 1985Li Huanwu b. 1986Li Shaowu b. 1995 ## Government offices held - [Lee Kuan Yew](/wiki/Lee_Kuan_Yew): [Member of Parliament](/wiki/Parliament_of_Singapore) 1955–2015; [Leader of the Opposition](/wiki/Leader_of_the_Opposition_(Singapore)), 1955–1959; [Prime Minister of Singapore](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Singapore), 1959–1990; [Senior Minister of Singapore](/wiki/Senior_Minister_of_Singapore), 1990–2004; [Minister Mentor of Singapore](/wiki/Minister_Mentor_of_Singapore), 2004–2011 - [Lee Hsien Loong](/wiki/Lee_Hsien_Loong): [Member of Parliament](/wiki/Parliament_of_Singapore) 1984–; Acting [Minister for Trade and Industry](/wiki/Ministry_of_Trade_and_Industry_(Singapore)#Ministers), 1986; [Second Minister for Defence (Services)](/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_(Singapore)), 1987–1990; [Minister for Trade and Industry](/wiki/Ministry_of_Trade_and_Industry_(Singapore)#Ministers), 1987–1992; [Deputy Prime Minister of Singapore](/wiki/Deputy_Prime_Minister_of_Singapore), 1990–2004; [Chairman of the Monetary Authority of Singapore](/wiki/Monetary_Authority_of_Singapore), 1998–2004; [Minister for Finance](/wiki/Minister_for_Finance_(Singapore)), 2001–2007; [Prime Minister of Singapore](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Singapore), 2004–2024; [Senior Minister of Singapore](/wiki/Senior_Minister_of_Singapore), 2024– - [Lee Wei Ling](/wiki/Lee_Wei_Ling): Director of the [National Neuroscience Institute](/wiki/National_Neuroscience_Institute), 2004–2014 - [Lee Hsien Yang](/wiki/Lee_Hsien_Yang): Chief Executive Officer of [Singtel](/wiki/Singtel), 1995–2007; Chairman of the [Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore](/wiki/Civil_Aviation_Authority_of_Singapore), 2009–2018 [Ho Ching](/wiki/Ho_Ching): Wife of [Lee Hsien Loong](/wiki/Lee_Hsien_Loong); Chief Executive Officer of [Temasek Holdings](/wiki/Temasek_Holdings), 2004–2021 ## 38 Oxley Road dispute [38 Oxley Road](/wiki/38_Oxley_Road) is an eight-bedroom two-storey [bungalow](/wiki/Bungalow#Singapore_and_Malaysia) located near [Orchard Road](/wiki/Orchard_Road), [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore). The house was built in the late 19th century and was the residence of the first [prime minister of Singapore](/wiki/Prime_minister_of_Singapore), [Lee Kuan Yew](/wiki/Lee_Kuan_Yew), from the 1940s until his death in 2015. The first meeting of the [People's Action Party](/wiki/People%27s_Action_Party) (PAP) occurred in the basement. In 2017, it became central to a dispute in Singapore among Lee's children, [Lee Hsien Loong](/wiki/Lee_Hsien_Loong), [Lee Hsien Yang](/wiki/Lee_Hsien_Yang) and [Lee Wei Ling](/wiki/Lee_Wei_Ling), over its use and demolition. Lee Kuan Yew had originally willed the house to Lee Hsien Loong, who later sold it to Lee Hsien Yang in 2015 at market price, on the condition that both of them would donate half of the value to charity. Lee's will included a condition that his daughter Lee Wei Ling be allowed to stay there. She died on 9 October 2024, opening a range of plausible options for the house as set out by the Ministerial Committee in 2018. The options are to (i) retain the property by gazetting it as a National Monument or for conservation; (ii) retain the dining room and demolish the rest of the property; or (iii) allow the property to be demolished fully and allow for the site to be redeveloped. In 2025, the government announced their intentions to gazette it as a [national monument](/wiki/National_monuments_of_Singapore). ## Relation to other prominent families Kwa Geok Choo, the wife of Lee Kuan Yew, is the daughter of Wee Yew Neo, who is in turn the sister of Helene Tan, wife of [Tan Chin Tuan](/wiki/Tan_Chin_Tuan). The Tans are another prominent family in Singapore, whose members include: - [Tony Tan](/wiki/Tony_Tan), the 7th [President of Singapore](/wiki/President_of_Singapore) - [Tan Kim Seng](/wiki/Tan_Kim_Seng), a Peranakan businessman - Tan Eng Sian, who the College of Alice and Peter Tan of the [National University of Singapore](/wiki/National_University_of_Singapore) is named after - [Simon Chesterman](/wiki/Simon_Chesterman), former dean of the [National University of Singapore Faculty of Law](/wiki/National_University_of_Singapore_Faculty_of_Law) The Lee family is also distantly related to [Teo Chee Hean](/wiki/Teo_Chee_Hean) through Kwa Geok Choo: - Choo's brother, [Kwa Soon Chuan](/wiki/Kwa_Soon_Chuan), was married to Ivy Lim Seok Cheng, the second daughter of [Lim Chong Pang](/wiki/Lim_Chong_Pang), who was in turn the son of [Lim Nee Soon](/wiki/Lim_Nee_Soon). - Kwa Soon Chuan's daughter was Kwa Kim-Li, who is the managing partner of [Lee & Lee](/wiki/Lee_%26_Lee). - Lim Nee Soon's maternal grandfather was Teo Lee, a predecessor of [Teo Eng Hock](/wiki/Teo_Eng_Hock), [Teo Soon Kim](/wiki/Teo_Soon_Kim), and Teo Chee Hean. - The Lims were also related to [Oei Tiong Ham](/wiki/Oei_Tiong_Ham) via Nee Soon's eldest daughter, who married a son of Oei. The Lee political family is also distantly related to the Lee family that founded the [Chinese Commercial Bank](/wiki/Chinese_Commercial_Bank), via Kwa Geok Choo: - Lim Chong Pang, the father-in-law of Choo's brother, Kwa Soon Chuan, was married to the daughter of [Lee Choon Guan](/wiki/Lee_Choon_Guan) and [Tan Teck Neo](/wiki/Tan_Teck_Neo). - Choon Guan was the son of [Lee Cheng Yan](/wiki/Lee_Cheng_Yan). - Teck Neo was the daughter of [Tan Keong Saik](/wiki/Tan_Keong_Saik), who [Keong Saik Road](/wiki/Keong_Saik_Road) is named after. - Lee Choon Guan was the cousin of Lee Keng Kiat, who is the father of Lee Chim Tuan and Lee Chim Huk. - Huk was the father of Lee Kip Lin and Lee Kip Lee, the latter being the father of Singaporean creative [Dick Lee](/wiki/Dick_Lee). - Tuan was a maternal cousin of Malaysian politician [Tan Cheng Lock](/wiki/Tan_Cheng_Lock).
title: Lee family (Singapore)
